ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Through this class, I learned a lot of introductory statistics knowledge. I became more proficient in R, I learned what linear regression was useful for, and I learned about many different types of statistical distributions.
Basic R coding; some data visualization; basic probability; distributions; regression models.

I learnt the basics of how to use R to compute statistics and plot graphs. Having not taken a statistics class before, this class was a comfortable introduction to the essentials of stats like random distributions, confidence intervals, and regression. The material that we were taught was easy enough but was perhaps a bit sparse. The class could feel fast some weeks, but it was pretty easy to catch up and understand the material.
Probabilities, distributions, regression, and how to do all of it in R
Basic intro statistics, some R
Learned basic stats, functions in R, regression, probability, visualizations, distributions.
Some knowledge of statistics; was made difficult by the fact that I had no prior knowledge of the subject although given that this was an intro course I thought that wouldnt be necessary
A good basis of r and beginners statistics
A basic introduction to statistics and some working familiarity with R
the basics of statistics, several different distribution, linear regression model

Learned how to do linear regression modeling in R.
Learned about probability theory, calculating standard deviation, confidence intervals, etc.
Knowledge of RStudio, graphing and data visualization, and introductory statistics
I gained a basic understanding of statistics: confidence internal, regression, and basic probability.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The professor's teaching style was a strength of this course, as he was always able to answer questions we had and stayed after class to help us with homework questions and our final project. 
A major weakness of this course was how long it took for each problem set to be graded. As a result, it would take a while before I knew what aspects I needed to improve in. A small weakness of the course is that the professor included questions in his slides for us to go over in class, but usually didn't include the answers in the slides. As such, when reviewing his slides for homeworks and exams, we would not know whether we were answering correctly or incorrectly if we didn't manage to write down the answer from class. I think this class would be improved with more guided problems during class on the slides.
Great professor, material, and problem sets. Not as intensive and code-heavy as Id expect, which can be good or bad depending on who you ask.

The strengths of this class are certainly Brian's enthusiasm and knowledge of statistics as well as the homeworks, which help understand the concepts very well. All notes and lectures are posted online, but that may have been a slight weakness as few people would attend the lectures. Another strength were our ULAs for the semester, who helped with homeworks generously. It was very easy to understand the concepts even without prior knowledge due to the logical progress that we made throughout the class, and Brian was helpful to clarify any material that wasn't clear or beyond the scope of the lecture.

Amongst the weaknesses, I would say the lectures were sometimes not terribly engaging due to being largely based off of the notes/slides on the topic. Plus it was at 9AM so energy was low for much of the semester.

Strengths: a decent introduction to the material
Weaknesses: Going to class wasn't worth it because Professor Macdonald would just read what was on the slides. The explanations for concepts were really hard to understand, and it felt like the practical applications of what we were doing weren't explained. Generally, I didn't feel like I came away with much knowledge at all, and if anything, less interest in doing more statistics.
More intensive, especially on R

Strengths: Good survey of stats, good way to get familiar with R, great and knowledgable professor, reasonable workload and exams

Weaknesses: I felt like it could have moved a bit faster so that we could have gotten to bootstrapping, ANOVA, and other important topics. Also more time could have been spent on doing regression calculations by hand so that we could have gotten a better conceptual intuition beyond mechanically creating models in R.

lectures/course time needs more practice problems or applications of concepts. also, more r practice or gaining of R Studio proficiency really really needs to be taught. if knowledge of r isnt prerequisite for the class but then it is in our assignments and not even really taught to ushow are we supposed to know how to use it?!
Give deeper explanation of the material.

Because we were learning statistics concepts and application (coding) at the same time it was difficult to really grasp anything. If I had taken AP Stats in high school I might have been better off but with no prior knowledge I feel I didnt get very much out of the course
The course was quite fast paced and did not go into much detail; a little hard to follow along

Strengths - very accessible helpful professor, great TAs, well-designed exams

Weaknesses  especially with a course that focusses on fundamental concepts like hypothesis testing and confidence intervals, they could be taught much better using real-world examples in class. What is bootstrapping? What does a confidence interval look like? What is a sample mean really - give examples for these. Some classes were far too slow (the introductions to probability in the first half) leaving less time to explore the fundamentals

strength: the course is quite easy to manage
weakness: maybe it's a bit too intro-like and I kind of hope it can go to a deeper level

Strengths: professor was helpful and generous
Weaknesses: lectures were a bit dry but otherwise give you a solid foundation in probability theory needed to work in R.
The course is fine, but it could use an easily accessible calendar beforehand so that we are aware of midterm dates and things of that nature

The course was aggressively fine. Lectures were not that engaging. Problem sets did serve to practice all the material that we would be assessed on. Office hours were incredibly useful and the main avenue I felt for engaging and improving my understanding of the material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to any student who is interested in getting an introduction to statistics at Yale and hasn't had previous experience in statistics.
Id recommend it to anyone interested in learning basic R and statistics up to regression models. Honestly not that intensive. Do the problem sets and read the lecture notes, and you should be good.

If they want to learn a bit of R while also garnering a solid foundation in statistics in a small class (about 20 in my class), I would recommend this class to a fellow student. Some may find Brian's style not as engaging, but I personally liked his humor-infused lectures that were also populated with anecdotes from his work as an actual data scientist/sports analyst.

No. After getting past the introductory stuff, the explanations for more intricate concepts were pretty bad. It often felt like we were just going through the motions of reading and applying formulas, with an unclear purpose. If you want to take an intro stats class, I would recommend something else.
Absolutely!! A great way to get a grasp on basic stats and also learn some R
Yes if they want an easy stats class that counts toward the major
I would recommend it! It's a good overview for someone who has never seen stats before.
no i likely wouldnt. not only is it a 9am, the class experience is just not engaging. statistics is interesting, but the delivery of lessons/concepts just wasnt giving
I would recommend a student in my position take the two-semester stats sequence (100 and 230) to fully grasp the concepts I was supposed to learn in 220
Only if they had some sort of basis to begin with

Yes, for lack of better S&DS alternatives. S&DS 100 classes are FAR too easy and honestly, a waste of time. S&DS 230 does not statistics. This is a good middle ground but needs to be changed to focus more on fundamental concepts in an illustrative way. I wish I came out of the class fully understanding what a p-value is but I don't.
yes to students who need basic stats background knowledge
A pretty good intro class -- don't know much about 230 or the 10x courses but this isn't too bad.
It is a great statistics course in of itself and very applicable, so yes, I would recommend!

Not really. I went into it hoping that I would get a better understanding of the math behind stats from a computational perspective (i.e. splitting between the 100s and 230). However, it overly compromised on both of these with I felt not a really in depth evaluation of the statistics and very very basic R.
